did.unittitle: Library Company of Philadelphia accession books

bioghist.p: The Library Company of Philadelphia is an independent research library concentrating on American society and culture from the 17th through 19th centuries. It was founded in 1731 by Benjamin Franklin as a subscription library supported by its shareholders, as it is to this day. Free and open to the public, the Library Company houses an extensive non-circulating collection of rare books, manuscripts, broadsides, ephemera, and works of art. The Loganian Library, created in 1754 as a trust for the public, was transferred to the Library Company in 1792. The nucleus of the Loganian Library was the personal library of James Logan, which at the time of his death in 1751 was one of the three largest private libraries in the colonies, and the strongest in scientific books. The Ridgway branch opened in 1878, and was located at Broad and Christian streets. It was named after Phoebe Ann Ridgway Rush, wife of James Rush.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of 32 accession books for the Ridgway branch of the Library Company and 5 accession books for the Loganian Library. The Ridgway accession books are duplicates of the original set of accession books maintained at the Library. Entries in the accession books include accession number, title, author, classification, city and date of publication, and occasional remarks. Accessions are arranged by the size of volume and then by accession number.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
